item.title: A new preferred way to call listKeys() in bicep
item.description:
After upgrading to Bicep CLI version 0.15.31 (3ba6e06a8d) I got a linter warning in one of my bicep files:

Use a resource reference instead of invoking function “listKeys”. This simplifies the syntax and allows Bicep to better understand your deployment dependency graph.bicep core https://aka.ms/bicep/linter/use-resource-symbol-reference

The offensive line was where I am reading the access key from a log analytics workspace:

listKeys(logAnalyticsWorkspace.id, logAnalyticsWorkspace.apiVersion).primarySharedKey

Unfortunately the URL in the linter message did not resolve to any help page but redirected me to bing instead.

So I tried my best guess as to what the linter tried to tell me and I got lucky:

logAnalyticsWorkspace.listKeys().primarySharedKey

The linter warning disappeared and my deployment continued to work just fine.

This syntax is indeed easier to read. I had no idea, that it was possible to use methods on symbolic references.

item.title: Query Azure Log Analytics from Logic App using Managed Identity
item.description:
While Azure Log Analytics Workspaces supports access using a Managed Identity (formally known as: Managed Service Identity, MSI), the official Logic Apps connector for Azure Log Analytics (Azure Monitor Logs) does not.

As a workaround queries to a Log Analytics Workspace can also be send directly to the Azure REST API, as the built-in HTTP connector in Logic Apps supports Managed Identities.

⌨️ I have added a minimal example to my bicep-snippets repository: bicep-snippets/logicapp-msi-workspace at mother · manualbashing/bicep-snippets (github.com)
